items.title: Cities Urge Public Pension Funds to Divest From Gun Makers
items.abstract: Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago urged the executives of two major banks to cease the financing of firearms companies. Other cities are making similar efforts.

items.title: Maker Hid Data About Design Flaw in Hip Implant, Records Show
items.abstract: Johnson & Johnson executives were aware that an artificial hip had a critical design flaw years before it was recalled, but concealed that information, according to documents disclosed at a trial.

items.title: Used Car Prices Vary by Market, Analysis Finds
items.abstract: When buying a car in a market a distance away, it pays to have a mechanic inspect the vehicle, the founder of a car selling Web site advises.

items.title: The Extraordinary Science of Addictive Junk Food
items.abstract: Inside the hyperengineered, savagely marketed, addiction-creating battle for American “stomach share.”

items.title: Schools, and Syllabuses, Designed With the Environment in Mind
items.abstract: A look at schools where design and teaching focus on energy and the environment.
keywords: Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED)

items.title: A Boutique for the Great Outdoors and the Urban Wild
items.abstract: Snow Peak, newly opened in Manhattan, is more than a camping store.

items.title: Intimate, Haunting Portraits of New York City Youth
items.abstract: The photographer (and model) Ethan James Green finds many of the subjects in his ongoing series of creatives on social media.

items.title: New York City’s Promising Step on Criminal Justice
items.abstract: A new bill could make many “quality of life” violations civil, not criminal, offenses, helping to ease the overpolicing in communities of color.

items.title: New York City’s Pension System in Danger of ‘Operational Failure,’ Report Says
items.abstract: The bureau managing the city’s retirement funds has not kept up with the times and lacks basic tools to identify risk, according to an independent report commissioned by the city comptroller’s office.

items.title: Christie Announces Plan for State Control of Atlantic City’s Finances
items.abstract: Under the agreement, New Jersey officials would be in charge of reducing the city’s debt of $240 million and making cuts to the size and cost of its civil services.

items.title: In High-Tech Cities, No More Potholes, but What About Privacy?
items.abstract: Cities, including some far from the coasts, are vying to use technology to guide services. But the race toward “smart cities” is raising privacy worries.

items.title: Some Workers Need Jobs as Much as Builders Need Workers. Cities Connect Them.
items.abstract: In tight labor markets, developers and local leaders are using major projects to provide residents with careers in construction.

items.title: Architects Wanted: Design These Odd Lots
items.abstract: New York City is holding a competition to create affordable housing on some of its most difficult properties.

items.title: New York Says It Will Crack Down on City Workers Abusing Parking Privileges
items.abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio pushes measures to cut down parking placard abuse, but does little to address criticism over soaring placard numbers.

items.title: Butter Designed to Impress
items.abstract: Thomas Keller and the designer Martin Kastner invented a tool to make the fancy butter curls at TAK Room in Hudson Yards.

items.title: Eric Adams Takes Office as New York City’s 110th Mayor at a Perilous Moment
items.abstract: Eric Adams, the city’s second Black mayor, faces difficult decisions over how to lead New York City through the next wave of the pandemic.

items.title: When Production Design Plays a Supporting Role
items.abstract: The visual environments of “West Side Story,” “The Humans” and “Nightmare Alley” feel as alive as the actors.

items.title: ‘Attempted Security Threat’ Disables Software at Some New York Schools
items.abstract: The outage in a platform used by teachers and students has caused another disruption for a system that has had its share amid the pandemic.
keywords: Goldstein, Leon M, High School for the Sciences (Brooklyn, NY)

items.title: A California City Is Overrun by Crows. Could a Laser Be the Answer?
items.abstract: In a move befitting its Silicon Valley setting, the city of Sunnyvale, Calif., will aim a laser at 1,000 birds that have overwhelmed the downtown area during the pandemic.
keywords: Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)

items.title: How a Boy in Rural Iceland Became a Tool for Global Fascism
items.abstract: “Red Milk,” a novel by Sjón, examines a young man’s path to neo-Nazism.
